message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Distributed Games with a Central Decision Maker
Paper Abstract: We study distributed games played on non-deterministic asynchronous automata which feature a central decision maker process that participates in all key decision making tasks. In these partial-information games, processes use their causal past to respond to scheduling choices made by the scheduler and cooperatively strategize as a team to achieve the winning objective. We show that the problem of deciding the existence of a distributed winning strategy is efficiently solvable for global safety and local parity objectives. We provide algorithmic solutions that match their computational hardness. We formulate the notion of a finite-state distributed strategy which allows to quantify its distributed memory requirements. For the aforementioned objectives, we establish that finite-state distributed winning strategies always exist. In fact, we provide novel constructions of such winning strategies which are shown to have almost optimal amount of distributed memory. We also show that a natural extension of the model with two decision making processes is undecidable.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the web search results for "Finite automata":

## Overview

A finite-state automaton (FSA) is a mathematical model of computation that is an abstract machine capable of being in exactly one of a finite number of states at any given time.

## Key Types

The main variants of finite automata include:

1. **Deterministic Finite Automata (DFA)**: A deterministic finite-state automaton is a finite-state machine that accepts or rejects a given string of symbols, by running through a state sequence uniquely determined by the string.

2. **Nondeterministic Finite Automata (NFA)**: A nondeterministic finite automaton does not need to obey the restrictions that each transition is uniquely determined by its source state and input symbol.

3. **Other Variants**: NFAs have been generalized in multiple ways, including nondeterministic finite automata with ε-moves, finite-state transducers, pushdown automata, alternating automata, ω-automata, and probabilistic automata.

## Equivalence and Recognition

DFAs and NFAs recognize exactly the set of regular languages.(no content)Every NFA can be translated to a DFA that recognizes the same language.

## Applications

In computer science, finite-state machines are widely used in modeling of application behavior (control theory), design of hardware digital systems, software engineering, compilers, network protocols, and computational linguistics.

Here are the web search results for "Finite automata":

## Overview

A finite-state automaton (FSA) is a mathematical model of computation that is an abstract machine capable of being in exactly one of a finite number of states at any given time.

## Key Types

The main variants of finite automata include:

1. **Deterministic Finite Automata (DFA)**: A deterministic finite-state automaton is a finite-state machine that accepts or rejects a given string of symbols, by running through a state sequence uniquely determined by the string.

2. **Nondeterministic Finite Automata (NFA)**: A nondeterministic finite automaton does not need to obey the restrictions that each transition is uniquely determined by its source state and input symbol.

3. **Other Variants**: NFAs have been generalized in multiple ways, including nondeterministic finite automata with ε-moves, finite-state transducers, pushdown automata, alternating automata, ω-automata, and probabilistic automata.

## Equivalence and Recognition

DFAs and NFAs recognize exactly the set of regular languages.(no content)Every NFA can be translated to a DFA that recognizes the same language.

## Applications

In computer science, finite-state machines are widely used in modeling of application behavior (control theory), design of hardware digital systems, software engineering, compilers, network protocols, and computational linguistics.

Web search results for query: "Information asymmetry"

Links: [{"title":"Information asymmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_asymmetry"},{"title":"The Market for Lemons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Market_for_Lemons"},{"title":"Agency cost - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agency_cost"},{"title":"Law School Transparency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_School_Transparency"},{"title":"Category:Asymmetric information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Asymmetric_information"},{"title":"Economic transparency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_transparency"},{"title":"Suelette Dreyfus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suelette_Dreyfus"},{"title":"Sharp power - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sharp_power"},{"title":"California Privacy Rights Act - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Privacy_Rights_Act"},{"title":"Z-channel (information theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z-channel_(information_theory)"}]

## Information Asymmetry

In contract theory, mechanism design, and economics, an information asymmetry is a situation where one party has more or better information than the other.

### Effects and Consequences

Information asymmetry creates an imbalance of power in transactions, which can sometimes cause the transactions to be inefficient, causing market failure in the worst case.(no content)Examples of this problem are adverse selection, moral hazard, and monopolies of knowledge.

### Real-World Applications

A classic example comes from the used car market. When a used car is sold, the seller is likely to have a much better understanding of the car's condition and hence its market value than the buyer, who can only estimate the market value based on the information provided by the seller and their own assessment of the vehicle.(no content)Information asymmetry extends to non-economic behaviour. Private firms have better information than regulators about the actions that they would take in the absence of regulation, and the effectiveness of a regulation may be undermined.

### Economic Recognition

In 1996, a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics was awarded to James A. Mirrlees and William Vickrey for their "fundamental contributions to the economic theory of incentives under asymmetric information". This led the Nobel Committee to acknowledge the importance of information problems in economics. They later awarded another Nobel Prize in 2001 to George Akerlof, Michael Spence, and Joseph E. Stiglitz for their "analyses of markets with asymmetric information".

Based on the search results, here's what I found about "Safety property":

## Safety Property in Computer Science

A safety property is a formal concept in computer science, particularly for concurrent and distributed systems, expressing the idea that "bad things don't happen". A safety property proscribes discrete bad things from occurring during an execution and characterizes what is permitted by stating what is prohibited.

### Definition and Examples

Safety properties are informally of the form "a bad thing does not happen", for instance, in an automated teller machine (ATM) system, "money should not be dispensed unless a PIN has been entered". Other examples include:

- Deadlock freedom is a safety property, where the "bad thing" is a deadlock
- Producing an answer within a specified real-time bound is a safety property, as a discrete bad thing is being proscribed—a partial execution that violates the time bound

### Relation to Other Properties

All properties of an execution are a conjunction of safety and liveness properties, where liveness properties represent "good things do happen". To verify a safety property, it is sufficient to consider only the finite traces of a system and check whether any such trace is a bad prefix.

Web search results for query: "Asynchronous automata"

Links: [{"title":"Asynchronous cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Input/output automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input/output_automaton"},{"title":"Cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_Automaton"},{"title":"Category:Automata (computation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automata_(computation)"},{"title":"Asynchrony - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous"},{"title":"Sequential logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequential_logic"},{"title":"Automata theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata_theory"},{"title":"Asynchronous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_system"},{"title":"Category:Cellular automata - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Cellular_automata"},{"title":"Automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automaton"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about asynchronous automata:

## Asynchronous Cellular Automata

An asynchronous cellular automaton is able to update individual cells independently, in such a way that the new state of a cell affects the calculation of states in neighbouring cells. This contrasts with traditional synchronous cellular automata where all cells update simultaneously.

A method discovered independently by K. Nakamura in the 1970s, T. Toffoli in the 1980s, and C. L. Nehaniv in 1998 allows one to emulate exactly the behaviour of a synchronous cellular automaton via an asynchronous one.(no content)As a consequence, asynchronous cellular automata are capable of emulating, e.g., Conway's Game of Life, of universal computation, and of self-replication.

## Applications and Real-World Modeling

The use of asynchronous models can allow an extra level of realism in the model.(no content)The random independent scheme could be appropriate for modelling social networks or communication in computer networks, the clocked scheme could be appropriate for modelling insect colonies, while the self-synchronous scheme could be applied to neural tissue.

## Input/Output Automata

Input/output automata provide a formal model, applicable in describing most types of an asynchronous concurrent system.(no content)The model presents an explicit method for describing and reasoning about system components such as processes and message channels that interact with one another, operating at arbitrary relative speeds.

Nehaniv in 1998 allows one to emulate exactly the behaviour of a synchronous cellular automaton via an asynchronous one.(no content)As a consequence, asynchronous cellular automata are capable of emulating, e.g., Conway's Game of Life, of universal computation, and of self-replication.

## Applications and Real-World Modeling

The use of asynchronous models can allow an extra level of realism in the model.(no content)The random independent scheme could be appropriate for modelling social networks or communication in computer networks, the clocked scheme could be appropriate for modelling insect colonies, while the self-synchronous scheme could be applied to neural tissue.

## Input/Output Automata

Input/output automata provide a formal model, applicable in describing most types of an asynchronous concurrent system.(no content)The model presents an explicit method for describing and reasoning about system components such as processes and message channels that interact with one another, operating at arbitrary relative speeds.

Links: [{"title":"Distributed computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_computing"},{"title":"Distributed Computing Environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_Computing_Environment"},{"title":"Distributed networking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_networking"},{"title":"Advances in Distributed Computing and Artificial Intelligence Journal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advances_in_Distributed_Computing_and_Artificial_Intelligence_Journal"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Grid computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grid_computing"},{"title":"Edge computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edge_computing"},{"title":"Parallel computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_computing"},{"title":"Cloud computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing"},{"title":"Cambridge Distributed Computing System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambridge_Distributed_Computing_System"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about distributed computing:

## Definition

Distributed computing is a field of computer science that studies distributed systems, defined as computer systems whose inter-communicating components are located on different networked computers.(no content)The components of a distributed system communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another in order to achieve a common goal.

## Key Characteristics

Three challenges of distributed systems are: maintaining concurrency of components, overcoming the lack of a global clock, and managing the independent failure of components. However, when a component of one system fails, the entire system does not fail.(no content)In distributed computing, each processor has its own private memory (distributed memory).

## Benefits and Applications

A well-designed distributed system is more scalable, more durable, more changeable, and more fine-tuned than a monolithic application deployed on a single machine.(no content)Examples of distributed systems vary from SOA-based systems to microservices to massively multiplayer online games to peer-to-peer applications.

## Costs

Distributed systems cost more than monolithic architectures, primarily due to increased needs for additional hardware, servers, gateways, firewalls, new subnets, proxies, and so on.

Distributed computing is fundamental to modern IT infrastructure, enabling the scalability and reliability needed for contemporary applications and services.

Links: [{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"List of games in game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_in_game_theory"},{"title":"Game Theory (band) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Theory_(band)"},{"title":"Combinatorial game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_game_theory"},{"title":"Behavioral game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_game_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Battle of the sexes (game theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_sexes_(game_theory)"},{"title":"Non-cooperative game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-cooperative_game_theory"},{"title":"Two-level game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-level_game_theory"},{"title":"Algorithmic game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_game_theory"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of game theory based on the search results:

## Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.

## History and Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Major Contributions

Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.(no content)John Maynard Smith was awarded the Crafoord Prize for his application of evolutionary game theory in 1999, and fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson.

## Key Subdivisions

The field includes several specialized areas such as cooperative game theory, non-cooperative game theory, combinatorial game theory, behavioral game theory, and algorithmic game theory, each focusing on different aspects of strategic decision-making and interactions among rational agents.

Links: [{"title":"Parity game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_game"},{"title":"Parity (sports) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_(sports)"},{"title":"Talk:Parity game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Parity_game"},{"title":"Parity (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Oliver Friedmann - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oliver_Friedmann"},{"title":"Mean payoff game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_payoff_game"},{"title":"Category:Parity (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Parity_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Parity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity"},{"title":"Thuuz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thuuz"},{"title":"Parity of zero - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parity_of_zero"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about **parity games**:

## Definition

A parity game is played on a colored directed graph, where each node has been colored by a priority, and two players, 0 and 1, move a shared token along the edges of the graph.

## Game Mechanics

Player 0 wins an infinite play if the highest priority of infinitely often occurring positions is even. The name "parity game" comes from this winning condition based on whether the highest priority that appears infinitely often is even or odd.

## Key Properties

Parity games are history-free determined, meaning that if a player has a winning strategy, that player has a winning strategy that depends only on the current board position, and not on the history of the play.

## Computational Complexity

Solving a parity game played on a finite graph means deciding which of the two players has a winning strategy, and this problem is in NP and co-NP, more precisely UP and co-UP, as well as in QP (quasipolynomial time).(no content)It remains an open question whether this decision problem is solvable in PTime.

## Applications

Parity game solving can be seen as the algorithmic backend to problems in automated verification and controller synthesis, and the model-checking problem for the modal μ-calculus is known to be equivalent to parity game solving.

Based on the search results, here's information about **parity games**:

## Definition

A parity game is played on a colored directed graph, where each node has been colored by a priority, and two players, 0 and 1, move a shared token along the edges of the graph.

## Game Mechanics

Player 0 wins an infinite play if the highest priority of infinitely often occurring positions is even. The name "parity game" comes from this winning condition based on whether the highest priority that appears infinitely often is even or odd.

## Key Properties

Parity games are history-free determined, meaning that if a player has a winning strategy, that player has a winning strategy that depends only on the current board position, and not on the history of the play.

## Computational Complexity

Solving a parity game played on a finite graph means deciding which of the two players has a winning strategy, and this problem is in NP and co-NP, more precisely UP and co-UP, as well as in QP (quasipolynomial time).(no content)It remains an open question whether this decision problem is solvable in PTime.

## Applications

Parity game solving can be seen as the algorithmic backend to problems in automated verification and controller synthesis, and the model-checking problem for the modal μ-calculus is known to be equivalent to parity game solving.

I've completed a web search for "Task scheduling" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Task scheduling is the action of assigning resources to perform tasks, where the resources may be processors, network links or expansion cards, and the tasks may be threads, processes or data flows.

## Types of Task Scheduling

There are several important scheduling contexts:

**Computing/Operating Systems**: The scheduler is an operating system module that selects the next jobs to be admitted into the system and the next process to run, and operating systems may feature up to three distinct scheduler types: a long-term scheduler, a mid-term scheduler, and a short-term scheduler.

**Parallel Task Scheduling**: Parallel task scheduling is an optimization problem in computer science and operations research.

**Windows Task Scheduler**: Task Scheduler is a job scheduler in Microsoft Windows that launches computer programs or scripts at pre-defined times or after specified time intervals.

## Scheduling Algorithms

Common algorithms include:
- First in, first out (FIFO), also known as first come, first served (FCFS), is the simplest scheduling algorithm
- Earliest deadline first (EDF) is a dynamic scheduling algorithm used in real-time operating systems that places processes in a priority queue where the process closest to its deadline will be the next to be scheduled

## Applications

In real-time environments, such as embedded systems for automatic control in industry, the scheduler must ensure that processes can meet deadlines; this is crucial for keeping the system stable.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
